headline.main: When Half a Mandate Is No Mandate at All: More on Play-or-Pay in the Senate

docs.abstract: With a health-care plan poised to come out of committee, it's worth taking one more look at how it structures the employer mandate.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, joined 13 Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee to approve the committee's health care bill, the only Republican to do so. For months, her support seemed pivotal to health care's overhaul in the Senate. For much of the public, it's puzzling that the politics of reshaping a sector that accounts for 16 percent of the G.D.P. should seemingly hinge on one senator.

headline.main: Why One Vote Matters in the Senate

headline.main: Live Blogging the Finance Panel Vote on Health Care Bill

docs.snippet: The Senate Finance Committee voted, 14-9, in favor of a bill that would overhaul the health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: After a five-hour hearing, the Senate Finance Committee voted, 14-9, in favor of a bill overhauling the health care system. The only Republican on the panel to vote in support of the proposal was Senator Olympia J. Snowe, who cautioned that her vote on Tuesday wasn't a forecast of how she might vote later on. See related article by The Times's David M. Herszenhorn and Robert Pear.

docs.lead_paragraph: After an insurance industry report said that premiums would rise sharply with the passage of comprehensive health care legislation, Jon Gruber, a health care economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said he evaluated the report Monday at the request of Senate Democrats and found it deeply flawed.

headline.main: M.I.T. Economist Rebuts Insurance Industry Report

docs.abstract: An M.I.T. health economist, at behest of Senate Democrats, analyzes insurance industry report and finds it deeply flawed.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: Tort reform is a rallying cry for many physicians who believe that excessive medical malpractice awards and skyrocketing liability premiums are at least partly to blame for rising health care costs. While Democrats have long resisted the notion that the system needs reform, supporters got a small boost in September when President Obama pledged $25 million to fund state projects exploring alternate strategies to the current system.
docs.abstract: Tort reform comes in a variety of flavors.
docs.snippet: Tort reform comes in a variety of flavors.
